ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
Data analysis, Q-Learning algorithms, some data visualization.
Blockchains, Pricing and other algorithms, Byzantine attacks etc.
Lots of very interesting stuff.
Big Data and Algorithms, and Crypto. Super interesting class! Prof. Schaefer was very knowledgeable and taught the class really well!

I learned about a wide range of the economic applications of algorithms, from pricing, to collusion to blockchain. The readings and assignments targeted a good mix of statistical concepts and higher-level real-world applications.
Learned how to analyze data on the Blockchain, some of the policy challenges around algorithmic collusion among pricing algorithms, and developed presentation skills
I learned a lot. Really great survey course not just for the theory but also very practical coding psets. I didnt have a coding background and really enjoyed this aspect
You learn a lot about how algorithms are used in the economy, and towards the end you get a pretty good understanding of blockchain as well.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Professor Schaefer is an absolute gem. The course is structured in a beautiful way that facilitates a lot of learning in a fairly low-stake environment.
The problem sets were challenging but very enjoyable, it was great to be able to work in groups for problem sets and presentations.
The discussions were amazing and there is very little to critique about this class, if at all.

The only very very minor weakness was that Problem Set 1 took a long time to code and to run, but I think Professor Schaefer will definitely fix this in future iterations!

Absolutely loved everything about the class. He planned the lectures very well, and having a combination of problem sets and presentations was very helpful in making sure we learn the nuances of the topics discussed in class.

The simulation-based PSETs were good opportunities to use practical coding skills and develop better understandings of how the algorithms we were actually learning about worked. The presentations were a great opportunity to pick a topic and understand it well enough to explain it to peers, and to learn about things from peers as well. OVerall I think the only way this course could be improved is if there were more presentations - I really enjoyed working on them!
Very interesting and informative lectures. The student presentations were great too but sometimes discussion wasn't great following the presentations.
Course structure was perfect and made this a very enjoyable course. No weaknesses at all!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
100% yes. This is the best CS + Econ intersection class at Yale. Professor Schaefer is kind, knowledgeable, and gives very interesting assignments. 
The workload is also very manageable and pretty well distributed. It even gets lighter after Spring Break, which is so nice as other classes really pick up. Fantastic course.
Yes, absolutely! He is a great professor!

Yes! Great intro course if you are new to these topics and have a good python background. It doesn't necessarily repeat any topics you would have taken from a CS algos class or even an applied math/statistics thing because it focuses a lot more on applicaitons.
Yes it's a very good cs econ intersection course, it really combines topics from both domains and talks about the impact on society.
I would absolutely recommend anything by Prof. Schaefer, who is unfortunately leaving Yale, but nonetheless is a great professor and so knowledgeable!
